what: Introduction to the ABS Data API
title: A Guide to the ABS API Datasets
text: Australian Bureau Statistics provides Data API based SDMX (Statistical Data Metadata eXchange) standard. RESTful web service allows programmatic access wide range ABS datasets without downloading large files. get_abs_data function provides simple interface query API, data parsed using readsdmx package. API particularly useful : SEIFA indices SA1 level (2011, 2016, 2021) Census 2021 data CED (Commonwealth Electoral Division) SED (State Electoral Division) levels Census 2011 data SA1 level (South Australia ) ABS statistical datasets

title: A Guide to the ABS API Datasets
text: get_abs_data function retrieves data ABS Data API specifying dataflow identifier.

title: A Guide to the ABS API Datasets
text: list_abs_dataflows function helps discover available dataflows ABS API.

title: A Guide to the ABS API Datasets
text: ABS provides data two main channels, advantages: Recommendation: * Use get_abs_data() CED-level Census data SEIFA indices * Use get_census_data() comprehensive SA1-level Census data

title: A Guide to the ABS API Datasets
text: SEIFA suite four indexes summarise different aspects socio-economic conditions. index ranks areas disadvantaged advantaged based Census data.

title: A Guide to the ABS API Datasets
text: SEIFA data includes four different indexes: IRSD (Index Relative Socio-economic Disadvantage): Summarises variables related disadvantage (e.g., low income, unemployment, qualifications) IRSAD (Index Relative Socio-economic Advantage Disadvantage): Summarises variables related advantage disadvantage IER (Index Economic Resources): Summarises variables related economic resources (income, housing costs, assets) IEO (Index Education Occupation): Summarises variables related education occupation

title: A Guide to the ABS API Datasets
text: index provides several measures: SCORE: actual index score (mean 1000, standard deviation 100) RWSR: Rank within State/Territory RWAR: Rank within Australia RWSP: Percentile within State/Territory RWAP: Percentile within Australia RWSD: Decile within State/Territory RWAD: Decile within Australia URP: Usual Resident Population

title: A Guide to the ABS API Datasets
text: CED data includes several dimension columns: REGION: CED code (numeric identifier) REGION_TYPE: Always “CED” dataflows STATE: State/Territory code (1=NSW, 2=VIC, 3=QLD, etc.) ObsDimension: time period (e.g., 2021) ObsValue: data value dimensions vary table (e.g., SEXP sex, PCHAR person characteristics)

title: A Guide to the ABS's Boundary Datasets
text: ABS provides boundary datasets part Australian Statistical Geography Standard (ASGS), framework collecting disseminating statistical data across geographic areas (ABS ASGS). datasets essential electoral analysis, electoral boundaries, CEDs, change periodically due population shifts redistributions. get_boundary_data function streamlines access datasets, allowing users retrieve correspondence tables converting data Census years, allocation tables mapping smaller areas larger ones, specific boundary definitions electoral postal areas. guide explains use datasets effectively, importance electoral studies, handle nuances like boundary changes time.

title: A Guide to the ABS's Boundary Datasets
text: Electoral boundaries evolve, making challenging compare election results across different years. example, division’s boundaries 2013 may differ significantly 2025. Correspondence tables help adjust historical election results current boundaries, enabling consistent trend analysis. Allocation tables map smaller areas, like Statistical Area Level 1 (SA1) Mesh Blocks (MB), larger electoral divisions, facilitating data aggregation mapping. Additionally, datasets like POA allocations allow converting election data postal codes, useful campaign targeting. integrating datasets Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) election data, researchers can analyse voting patterns alongside demographic factors like income education Census.

title: A Guide to the ABS's Boundary Datasets
text: get_boundary_data function retrieves ABS boundary datasets, leveraging internal metadata map parameters specific files. downloads data ABS servers, typically Excel CSV format, returns data frame. Users can specify dataset reference date (ref_date), geographic level (level), data type (type), options retrieve raw processed data. function particularly useful aligning AEC election data, often provided SA1 level, electoral boundaries may defined using MBs units.

title: A Guide to the ABS's Boundary Datasets
text: Correspondence Tables: Convert data different boundary sets Census years (e.g., 2011 SA1 2016 SA1), providing proportional allocations based population area overlap. Allocation Tables: Assign smaller geographic units (e.g., SA1, MB) larger ones (e.g., CED, SED), indicating larger area smaller unit belongs .

title: A Guide to the ABS's Boundary Datasets
text: Boundary Changes: CEDs SEDs switched SA1-based MB-based allocations 2021, requiring MB SA1 allocation tables consistency AEC data. Use cases: Historical research: Analyse elections original boundary context academic studies Census alignment: Link Census data published period-specific CED approximations Redistribution impact analysis: Compare votes count old vs new boundaries Media archives: Recreate historical election maps validate old publications State election comparisons: Align federal results state electoral boundaries era Notes: 2022 election 2023 referendum used identical boundaries (2021 CEDs Vic/WA adjustments) See Valid Combinations Reference table supported event/boundary combinations

title: A Guide to the ABS Census Datasets
text: Australian Bureau Statistics (ABS) conducts Census Population Housing every five years, collecting data key characteristics people dwellings Australia. Census provides comprehensive snapshot nation, covering demographics, education, employment, income, housing, . data published various products including DataPacks, Community Profiles, GeoPackages. get_census_data function provides access Census DataPacks SA1 geographic level. SA1s smallest geographic unit Census data publicly released, containing approximately 200-800 people. granular level data particularly useful linking Census demographics electoral results.

title: A Guide to the ABS Census Datasets
text: get_census_data function retrieves Census data ABS DataPacks, downloading extracting specific tables ZIP archives hosted ABS website. table contains different Census variables organised topic.

title: A Guide to the ABS Census Datasets
text: Census DataPacks contain different profile types depending year: General Community Profile (GCP): Used 2016 2021 Census. Tables prefixed “G” (e.g., G01, G02). Contains approximately 60 tables covering major Census topics. Basic Community Profile (BCP): Used 2011 Census. Tables prefixed “B” (e.g., B01, B02). Contains approximately 46 tables core Census variables.

title: A Guide to the ABS Census Datasets
text: tables organised topic: Person Characteristics: Age, sex, marital status, ancestry, country birth, language, religion Education: School attendance, highest year school, qualifications, field study Employment: Labour force status, occupation, industry, hours worked, income Family & Household: Family composition, household composition, number children Housing: Dwelling structure, tenure, mortgage, rent, bedrooms, motor vehicles Health & Assistance: Long-term health conditions, need assistance, unpaid care

title: A Guide to the ABS Census Datasets
text: ABS collects Census data national Census conducted every five years. data processed, quality-checked, released approximately 12-18 months Census night. DataPacks made available CSV format within ZIP archives, organised geographic level. Key points data: Confidentiality: Small random adjustments made cell values protect respondent confidentiality Geographic Structure: SA1s building blocks Australian Statistical Geography Standard (ASGS), nesting within SA2, SA3, SA4, State/Territory boundaries Comparability: many tables consistent across years, topics available certain Census years (e.g., health conditions 2021 )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Disclosure Datasets
text: Transparency Register, hosted Australian Electoral Commission (AEC), comprehensive database compiles financial disclosure information submitted various political entities. entities include registered political parties, significant third parties, associated entities, members parliament, senators, donors, others involved electoral processes. register’s primary purpose inform public allow scrutiny financial activities impact elections, mandated Part XX Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (AEC Financial Disclosure). register organises data three main types returns: Annual Returns: cover financial activities financial year (July 1 June 30), including donations, expenditures, debts, financial details. published first business day February year (AEC Annual Returns). Election Returns: pertain federal elections -elections, detailing donations electoral expenditures specific events. published 24 weeks polling day. Referendum Returns: relate referendums, capturing financial information donations expenditures, published 24 weeks voting day (AEC Transparency Register). Transparency Register faced temporary outage 15 May 2024 due privacy issue involving publication candidates’ postal addresses. external review led eight recommendations, accepted AEC, improve data handling (AEC Transparency FAQs). AEC made necessary changes register, now back online without sensitive information.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Disclosure Datasets
text: get_disclosure_data function, simplifies access Transparency Register’s datasets. function takes three parameters: type: Specifies return type (Annual, Election, Referendum), defaulting Annual. group: Indicates entity category, Donor, Party, Candidate, Third Party, defaulting Donor provided. file_name: Denotes specific dataset, Donations Made Returns, defaulting Donations Made specified. function validates inputs predefined options retrieves data zipped folders AEC’s Transparency Register download page (AEC Downloads). combinations type, group, file_name valid; function checks valid datasets using internal index (aec_disclosure_index) within scgElectionsAU package.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Disclosure Datasets
text: Transparency Register offers various datasets, corresponding specific aspect financial disclosure. summary datasets accessible via get_disclosure_data function, organized file_name: datasets available different groups types, outlined examples . instance, Donations Made Donor Annual return lists contributions political entities, Returns Party includes required financial disclosures.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Disclosure Datasets
text: datasets governed Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, mandates financial disclosure maintain electoral integrity. 2023–24 financial year, disclosure threshold $16,300, indexed annually July 1 (AEC Media Release). Entities must lodge returns AEC’s eReturns portal, annual returns due October 20 (November 17 MPs Senators) election/referendum returns due 24 weeks event. Significant reforms funding disclosure scheme scheduled July 1, 2026, affect 2025 federal election returns. changes include: Reducing disclosure threshold $5,000, indexed post-election. Introducing expedited disclosure donations $5,000 (e.g., within 7 days election periods). Implementing donation caps (e.g., $50,000 annually per recipient) expenditure caps (e.g., $90 million parties federally). Requiring federal accounts electoral expenditure donations. Shifting calendar-year reporting period replacing election returns expedited disclosures (AEC Legislative Changes). Minor amendments, changes registration processes, take effect February 21, 2025, unlikely impact dataset structures significantly.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: AEC provides comprehensive data Australia’s electoral processes Tally Room (AEC Tally Room) downloads pages (AEC Downloads). datasets include national, state, divisional, polling place results federal elections, -elections, referendums, governed Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. enable analysis voter behaviour, candidate performance, electoral trends, supporting transparency Australia’s democratic process. get_election_data function streamlines access datasets, offering flexibility retrieve raw processed data research public interest.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: get_election_data function retrieves raw AEC data optional processing, using internal aec_elections_index dataset map parameters specific files. downloads data AEC’s website, typically CSV format. Users can specify dataset, election type, data category, time period, option disable processing raw outputs. retrieving data multiple elections, function combines data single data frame, event column distinguishing election, facilitating longitudinal analysis.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: datasets organised categories: Candidates & Nominations: Candidate lists, nomination statistics state, division, gender. Seats: Data electoral divisions, including changes party control decision methods. First Preferences: Vote counts first preferences party, candidate, polling place levels. Two Party Preferred (TPP): Results two major parties (Coalition Labor). Two Candidate Preferred (TCP): Results top two candidates division. Distribution Preferences: Detailed preference flows preferential voting. Flow Preferences: preferences distributed among parties candidates. Votes: Informal votes, turnout, vote types (e.g., postal, pre-poll). General: Political parties, polling places, enrolment statistics. Statistics: Postal pre-poll voting, votes SA1, overseas voting.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: AEC collects election data electoral processes, publishing results via Tally Room downloads pages. Data typically available CSV TAB format shortly election, final results confirmed weeks later. scgElectionsAU package standardises datasets consistency across years, handling variations column names formats. Users verify dataset availability specific elections, datasets (e.g., “Votes SA1”) available later years.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: following sections detail datasets available return type, including example usage get_election_data function sample data output.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: National list candidates dataset contains comprehensive list candidates participated Australian federal elections. covers Senate House elections 2004 present type=-Election. 2004 dataset processed following way: SittingMemberFl column renamed Elected using process_elected() function. Based column, data standardised match later years “Y” “N” values inputted. replaces original corresponding “#” NA values. dataset enables : View candidate details (CandidateID, Surname, GivenNm) party affiliations (PartyAb, PartyNm). Map candidates electoral divisions (DivisionID, DivisionNm) states (StateAb). Identify elected candidates (Elected) incumbents (HistoricElected). NB. consistent pattern candidates retain candidate ID (CandidateID) . candidates appear retain across elections, others . therefore column correctly identify candidates across elections. Instead used across datasets single election.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Members elected Senators elected datasets provide comprehensive lists elected Members Parliament (MPs) Senators federal elections. datasets cover elections 2004 present available House Senate, respectively. title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Turnout state dataset provides summary voter turnout, detailing: state details (StateAb, StateNm). number voters enrolled (Enrolment). number percentage voters voted (Turnout, TurnoutPercentage). overall swing turnout compared previous election (TurnoutSwing). Covering elections 2004 present, dataset available House, Senate, Referendum. changes made.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Turnout by state",   date_range = list(from = "2004-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   # type = "Referendum", (for Referendum)   category = "House" # OR "Senate" OR "Referendum" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Turnout division dataset breaks figures division (DivisionID,DivisionNm).

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Turnout by division",   date_range = list(from = "2004-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   # type = "Referendum", (for Referendum)   category = "House" # OR "Senate" OR "Referendum" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Votes state dataset provides number votes vote type, detailing: state details (StateAb, StateNm). number voters enrolled (Enrolment). number votes vote type (OrdinaryVotes, AbsentVotes, ProvisionalVotes, DeclarationPrePollVotes, PostalVotes). total number votes percentage (TotalVotes, TotalPercentage). Covering elections 2004 present, dataset available House, Senate Referendum. Minor amendments made original dataset, changing PrePollVotes DeclarationPrePollVotes. ensures consistency column names across datasets.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Votes by state",   date_range = list(from = "2004-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   # type = "Referendum", (for Referendum)   category = "House" # OR "Senate" OR "Referendum" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Votes division dataset breaks figures division (DivisionID,DivisionNm).

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Votes by division",   date_range = list(from = "2004-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   # type = "Referendum", (for Referendum)   category = "House" # OR "Senate" OR "Referendum" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Votes polling place dataset breaks figures division (PollingPlaceID,PollingPlaceNm). Referendum.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Votes by polling place",   date_range = list(from = "2023-01-01", to = "2024-01-01"),   type = "Referendum",   category = "Referendum" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Political parties dataset provides summary political parties represented election, detailing: state details (StateAb). party details (PartyAb, PartyNm), including registered party name (RegisteredPartyAb). Covering elections 2004 present, dataset available General category. changes made.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Political parties",   date_range = list(from = "2004-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   category = "General" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Polling places dataset provides summary polling places used election, detailing: division details (StateAb, DivisionID, DivisionNm). polling place details (PollingPlaceID, PollingPlaceTypeID, PollingPlaceNm). address polling place (PremisesAddress1, PremisesAddress2, PremisesAddress3, PremisesSubrub, PremisesStateAb, PremisesPostCode). coordinates polling place (Latitude, Longitude). Covering elections 2004 present, dataset available General category. dataset processed following way, using process_coords() function: NA 0 values Latitude Longitude replaced known, based matching PollingPlaceID column within internal dataset dataset retrieved AEC.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Polling places",   date_range = list(from = "2004-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "Referendum", "By-Election"), # Any or All   category = "General",   process = TRUE # OR FALSE )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Enrolment state dataset provides summary enrolment, detailing: state details (StateAb, StateNm). number enrolments based type (CloseOfRollsEnrolment,NotebookRollAdditions,NotebookRollDeletions,ReinstatementsPrePoll,ReinstatementsAbsent,ReinstatementsProvisional). overall number enrolled voters (Enrolment). Covering elections 2004 present, dataset available General category. changes made.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Enrolment by state",   date_range = list(from = "2004-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "Referendum"), # Any or All   category = "General" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Enrolment division dataset breaks figures division (DivisionID,DivisionNm).

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Enrolment by division",   date_range = list(from = "2004-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "Referendum"), # Any or All   category = "General" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Declaration votes issued state Declaration votes received state datasets provide summary number declaration votes issued received, respectively, detailing: state details (StateAb, StateNm). number declaration votes type (Provisional,Absent,PrePoll,PrePollOwnDivision,Postal,PostalOwnDivision). Covering elections 2004 present, dataset available General category. changes made.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Declaration votes issued by state", # OR Declaration votes received by state   date_range = list(from = "2004-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "Referendum"), # Any or All   category = "General" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Declaration votes issued division Declaration votes received division datasets break figures division (DivisionID,DivisionNm).

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Declaration votes issued by division", # OR Declaration votes received by division   date_range = list(from = "2004-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "Referendum"), # Any or All   category = "General" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: <br

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Postal vote applications total dataset provides summary number postal vote applications received postal votes returned, detailing: division details (StateAb, DivisionNm). number valid applications received (Valid Applications Received). number postal votes returned (Postal Votes Returned). Covering the2022 election , dataset available Statistics category. changes made.

previous_headings: Statistics > Postal vote applications by total
title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Postal vote applications by total",   date_range = list(from = "2022-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "Referendum", "By-Election"), # Any or All   category = "Statistics" )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Postal vote applications date dataset provides summary number postal votes returned day, detailing: division details (StateAb, DivisionNm). date postal vote received (DateReceived). total number postal votes received (TotalPVAs). Covering elections 2010 2019, dataset available Statistics category. dataset processed following way, using process_pva_date() function: column names standardised, including Enrolment, Enrolment Division, PVA_Web_2_Date_Div PVA_Web_2_V2_Div renamed DivisionNm State_Cd StateAb. Unnecessary columns dropped, including <>, TOTAL date(Inc GPV), Date range. date columns pivoted wide long converted date format ease comparison across years.

previous_headings: Statistics > Postal vote applications by date
title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Postal vote applications by date",   date_range = list(from = "2010-01-01", to = "2022-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "By-Election"), # Any or All   category = "Statistics",   process = TRUE # OR FALSE )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Postal vote applications party dataset provides summary number postal votes returned day, detailing: division details (StateAb, DivisionNm). number General Postal Voters (GPV) - voters automatically receive ballot papers via post generally include voters disability, silent electors, prisoners, remote areas, unable attend polling place election day due religious objections. number AEC-received postal vote applications method received (AEC (Online), AEC (Paper), AEC (Total)). number party-received postal vote applications (ALP, CLP, DEM, LIB, LNP, NAT, OTH). total number AEC party received postal vote applications (Total (AEC + Parties)). Covering elections 2010 2019, dataset available Statistics category. dataset processed following way, using process_pva_party() function: column names standardised, including abbreviating party names.

previous_headings: Statistics > Postal vote applications by party
title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Postal vote applications by party",   date_range = list(from = "2010-01-01", to = "2022-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "By-Election"), # Any or All   category = "Statistics",   process = TRUE # OR FALSE )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Pre-poll votes dataset provides summary number prepoll votes issued, detailing: polling place details (StateAb, DivisionNm, PollingPlaceNm). date pre-poll vote issued (IssueDate). total number prepoll votes issued (TotalPPVs). Covering elections 2010 present, dataset available Statistics category. dataset processed following way, using process_ppv() function: column names standardised. date columns pivoted wide long converted date format ease comparison across years.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Pre-poll votes",   date_range = list(from = "2010-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "Referendum", "By-Election"), # Any or All   category = "Statistics",   process = TRUE # OR FALSE )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Votes SA1 dataset provides summary number votes SA1, detailing: SA1 details (StateAb, DivisionNm, PollingPlaceID, PollingPlaceNm, StatisticalAreaID). indicative count otes cast per SA1 (Count). Covering elections 2013 present, dataset available Statistics category. dataset processed following way, using process_ccd() function: column names standardised year column removed.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Votes by SA1",   date_range = list(from = "2013-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "Referendum"), # Any or All   category = "Statistics",   process = TRUE # OR FALSE )

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
text: Overseas dataset provides summary breakdown overseas voting, detailing: overseas post (OverseasPost). division votes cast (StateAb, DivisionNm). total number votes (TotalVotes), broken postal prepoll voting types (PostalVotes,PrePollVotes). Covering elections 2013 present, dataset available Statistics category. dataset processed following way, using process_overseas() function: column names standardised pp_sort_nm Total columns removed. TotalVotes column calculated based sum PostalVotes PrePollVotes.

title: A Guide to the AEC's Election Datasets
code: df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "Overseas",   date_range = list(from = "2013-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   type = c("Federal Election", "Referendum"), # Any or All   category = "Statistics",   process = TRUE # OR FALSE )

title: An R Package for Australian Election Data
text: scgElectionsAU R package providing comprehensive data tools analysing Australia’s federal election results 2004 2025. offers unique insight dynamics electoral process Australia, presented variety datasets functions.

title: An R Package for Australian Election Data
text: get_election_data: download process election data Australian Electoral Commission (AEC). See full guide . get_disclosure_data: download disclosure/financial data AEC’s Transparency Register. See full guide . get_boundary_data: download boundary data Australian Bureau Statistics (ABS). See full guide .

title: An R Package for Australian Election Data
text: install development version scgElectionsAU, use:
code: devtools::install_github("sarahcgallLtd/scgElectionsAU")

title: An R Package for Australian Election Data
text: scgElectionsAU includes several helper functions enhance data analysis: Example usage: Explore detailed examples dataset descriptions package documentation.
code: library(scgElectionsAU)  # Load a dataset df <- get_election_data(   file_name = "National list of candidates",   date_range = list(from = "2022-01-01", to = "2025-01-01"), # for elections between 2022 and 2025 (default)   type = "Federal Election", # Default (other options: "Referendum", or "By-Election")   category = "House", # Default (other options: "Senate", "Referendum", "General", or "Statistics")   process = TRUE # Default (can turn off automated processing by selecting FALSE) )

text: dataset containing table numbers descriptions ABS Census DataPack tables. can used look data table contains downloading get_census_data.

title: ABS Census Table Descriptions — abs_census_tables
code: abs_census_tables

title: ABS Census Table Descriptions — abs_census_tables
text: data frame 108 rows 3 variables: table Character. table identifier (e.g., "G01", "B01"). Tables G-prefix General Community Profile (2016, 2021). Tables B-prefix Basic Community Profile (2011). description Character. description table contents. census_years Character. Comma-separated list Census years table available (e.g., "2016,2021" "2011").

title: ABS Census Table Descriptions — abs_census_tables
text: Australian Bureau Statistics Census DataPacks https://www.abs.gov.au/census/find-census-data/datapacks

title: ABS Census Table Descriptions — abs_census_tables
text: ABS Census DataPacks contain pre-defined tables Census data SA1 geographic level. table numbering differs Census years: 2021 2016: Use General Community Profile (GCP) tables G-prefix (G01 G62) 2011: Uses Basic Community Profile (BCP) tables B-prefix (B01 B46) Note tables available certain Census years. example, tables G19-G22 (health conditions defence force service) available 2021 Census.

what: Amend Names in a Data Frame Column — amend_names
title: Amend Names in a Data Frame Column — amend_names

what: Retrieve data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Data API — get_abs_data
title: Retrieve data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Data API — get_abs_data
text: Downloads data ABS Data API (SDMX RESTful web service) specified dataflows SA1 CED geographic levels. provides access SEIFA indices, Census data, ABS datasets without downloading large DataPack files.

title: Retrieve data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Data API — get_abs_data
code: get_abs_data(   dataflow,   filter = NULL,   start_period = NULL,   end_period = NULL,   cache = TRUE )

title: Retrieve data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Data API — get_abs_data
text: dataflow Character. dataflow identifier query. Common options include: "ABS_SEIFA2021_SA1": SEIFA 2021 indices SA1 level "ABS_SEIFA2016_SA1": SEIFA 2016 indices SA1 level "C21_G01_CED": Census 2021 G01 (Selected person characteristics) CED level "C21_G02_CED": Census 2021 G02 (Medians averages) CED level "ABS_CENSUS2011_B01_SA1_SA": Census 2011 B01 SA1 level (SA ) Use list_abs_dataflows see available dataflows. filter Character NULL. Optional SDMX filter expression subset data. Use "" NULL data. Filter format depends dataflow structure - see ABS Data API documentation details. start_period Character NULL. Start period time series data (e.g., "2021"). end_period Character NULL. End period time series data (e.g., "2021"). cache Logical. TRUE (default), caches downloaded data session, making subsequent identical requests instant. Set FALSE always download fresh data.

title: Retrieve data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Data API — get_abs_data
text: data frame containing requested data columns dimension observation values.

title: Retrieve data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Data API — get_abs_data
text: function queries ABS Data API https://data.api.abs.gov.au/rest/. API uses SDMX (Statistical Data Metadata eXchange) standard, data parsed using readsdmx package. Key points: SA1 CED level data available select datasets (SEIFA, Census tables) Census tables available via API - full Census coverage SA1 level, use get_census_data downloads DataPacks Large queries (e.g., SEIFA SA1 level) may take time first request; caching makes subsequent requests instant Use clear_cache remove cached data needed.

title: Retrieve data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Data API — get_abs_data
text: SEIFA 2021 2016 indices Census 2011 Basic Community Profile tables (SA )

text: Census 2021 General Community Profile tables (G01-G62)

title: Retrieve data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Data API — get_abs_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get SEIFA 2021 data for all SA1s seifa <- get_abs_data("ABS_SEIFA2021_SA1")  # Get Census 2021 G01 data for all CEDs g01_ced <- get_abs_data("C21_G01_CED")  # Get data with time period filter seifa_2021 <- get_abs_data("ABS_SEIFA2021_SA1",                            start_period = "2021",                            end_period = "2021")  # Second call uses cache - instant! seifa_2021_again <- get_abs_data("ABS_SEIFA2021_SA1",                                   start_period = "2021",                                   end_period = "2021") } # }

what: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) boundary data — get_boundary_data
title: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) boundary data — get_boundary_data
text: Downloads processes ABS boundary data (allocation correspondence files) specified reference year geographic level scgElectionsAU package. special case 2011 SA1 correspondence data, handles multiple sheets Excel file performs additional data cleaning.

title: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) boundary data — get_boundary_data
code: get_boundary_data(   ref_date,   level = c("CED", "SED", "POA", "SA1", "MB"),   type = c("allocation", "correspondence"),   cache = TRUE )

title: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) boundary data — get_boundary_data
text: ref_date Numeric. reference year boundary data. Must 2011 2024, inclusive. level Character. geographic level boundary data. One "CED" (Commonwealth Electoral Division), "SED" (State Electoral Division), "POA" (Postal Area), "SA1" (Statistical Area Level 1), "MB" (Mesh Block). Defaults "CED". type Character. type boundary data. One "allocation" "correspondence". Defaults "allocation". cache Logical. TRUE (default), caches downloaded processed data session, making subsequent identical requests instant. Set FALSE always download fresh data.

title: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) boundary data — get_boundary_data
text: data frame containing boundary data specified parameters. multiple files downloaded, combined single data frame, provided identical column structures. 2011 SA1 correspondence data, additional cleaning performed ensure data consistency.

title: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) boundary data — get_boundary_data
text: function retrieves boundary data accessing abs_boundary_index dataset scgElectionsAU package, filtering based provided ref_date, level, type. downloads corresponding files URLs listed index using scgUtils::get_file(). multiple files retrieved, combined single data frame using rbind. special case ref_date = 2011, level = "SA1", type = "correspondence", function downloads multiple sheets Excel file (sheets 4 7), corrects known column name typo ("SA1_7DIGICODE_2011" "SA1_7DIGITCODE_2011"), performs additional data cleaning steps, renaming columns (e.g., "CD_CODE_2006...2" "CD_CODE_2006"), removing redundant columns (e.g., "CD_CODE_2006...1"), removing rows NA values. function includes validation checks ensure parameters valid downloaded data can combined. Use clear_cache remove cached data needed.

title: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) boundary data — get_boundary_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Retrieve 2024 CED allocation data ced_data <- get_boundary_data(ref_date = 2024, level = "CED", type = "allocation")  # Retrieve 2021 SA1 correspondence data (from 2016 to 2021) sa1_data <- get_boundary_data(ref_date = 2021, level = "SA1", type = "correspondence")  # Retrieve 2011 SA1 correspondence data (special case) sa1_2011_data <- get_boundary_data(ref_date = 2011, level = "SA1", type = "correspondence")  # Second call uses cache - instant! sa1_2011_data2 <- get_boundary_data(ref_date = 2011, level = "SA1", type = "correspondence") } # }

what: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Census data — get_census_data

title: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Census data — get_census_data
text: census_year Numeric. Census year. Must one 2011, 2016, 2021. table Character. table number retrieve (e.g., "G01", "G02"). See abs_census_table list available tables descriptions. cache Logical. TRUE (default), caches downloaded DataPack ZIP file session, making subsequent requests tables Census year much faster. Set FALSE always download fresh.

title: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Census data — get_census_data
text: data frame containing Census data specified table SA1 level.

title: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Census data — get_census_data
text: function retrieves Census data ABS DataPacks, ZIP archives containing CSV files Census data SA1 geographic level. function: Validates input parameters Downloads DataPack ZIP (uses cached version available) Extracts specified table ZIP archive Note : 2021 2016 Census use General Community Profile (GCP) tables (G01, G02, etc.) 2011 Census uses Basic Community Profile (BCP) tables (B01, B02, etc.) DataPacks large (100-400MB), first download takes time cache = TRUE, subsequent table requests fast Use clear_cache remove cached files needed

title: Retrieve Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Census data — get_census_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Retrieve table G01 (Selected Person Characteristics) for 2021 # First call downloads the DataPack (~380MB) g01 <- get_census_data(census_year = 2021, table = "G01")  # Second call uses cached ZIP - much faster! g02 <- get_census_data(census_year = 2021, table = "G02")  # Retrieve 2016 Census data g01_2016 <- get_census_data(census_year = 2016, table = "G01")  # Retrieve 2011 Census data (uses B prefix) b01_2011 <- get_census_data(census_year = 2011, table = "B01")  # Clear cached files when done (optional - clears automatically when session ends) clear_cache() } # }

what: Download and Process AEC Data — get_election_data
title: Download and Process AEC Data — get_election_data
text: function downloads processes data Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) based user-specified criteria file name, date range, election type, data category. retrieves raw data files AEC, optionally applies standardisation processes (e.g., column name consistency), returns combined data frame analysis. function designed handle various types election-related datasets, including federal elections, referendums, -elections.

title: Download and Process AEC Data — get_election_data
code: get_election_data(   file_name,   date_range = list(from = "2025-01-01", to = "2026-01-01"),   type = NULL,   category = c("House", "Senate", "Referendum", "General", "Statistics"),   process = TRUE,   cache = TRUE )

title: Download and Process AEC Data — get_election_data
text: file_name character string specifying name AEC dataset retrieve (e.g., "National list candidates"). name must match entries internal index datasets. date_range list two elements, "" "", specifying start end dates ("YYYY-MM-DD" format) election events include. Defaults list(= "2022-01-01", = "2025-01-01"). type character string specifying type election event. Must one : "Federal Election", "Referendum", "-Election", "Disclosure". Defaults first option. category character string specifying category data. Must one : "House", "Senate", "Referendum", "General", "Statistics". Defaults first option. process logical value indicating whether apply additional processing downloaded data, standardizing column names. Defaults TRUE. cache Logical. TRUE (default), caches downloaded processed data session, making subsequent identical requests instant. Set FALSE always download fresh data.

title: Download and Process AEC Data — get_election_data
text: data frame containing combined AEC data specified criteria. data frame includes metadata columns (e.g., date, event) optionally processed consistency process = TRUE. data available given parameters, function stops informative error message.

title: Download and Process AEC Data — get_election_data
text: get_election_data function automates retrieval processing AEC datasets : Validating input parameters ensure correctness. Checking data already cached (cache = TRUE). Retrieving internal metadata election events within specified date_range matching type. Checking availability requested file_name category internal index datasets. Constructing download URLs retrieving raw data files AEC website. Optionally preprocessing postal vote data standardizing column names. Combining data multiple election events single data frame. Caching result future identical requests (cache = TRUE). function relies internal helper functions (e.g., check_params, construct_url, preprocess_pva) datasets (e.g., info, aec_elections_index) within scgElectionsAU package. also uses scgUtils::get_file downloading files. function designed robust, providing clear messages errors guide users data retrieval process. Use clear_cache remove cached data needed.

title: Download and Process AEC Data — get_election_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   # Retrieve and process the national list of candidates for House elections in 2022   # First call downloads from AEC   data <- get_election_data(     file_name = "National list of candidates",     date_range = list(from = "2022-01-01", to = "2023-01-01"),     type = "Federal Election",     category = "House",     process = FALSE   )    # Second identical call uses cache - instant!   data2 <- get_election_data(     file_name = "National list of candidates",     date_range = list(from = "2022-01-01", to = "2023-01-01"),     type = "Federal Election",     category = "House",     process = FALSE   )    # Clear cache when done (optional - clears automatically when session ends)   clear_cache() } # }

what: Prepare Boundary Correspondence for Cross-Election Comparison — prepare_boundaries
title: Prepare Boundary Correspondence for Cross-Election Comparison — prepare_boundaries
text: Creates correspondence table maps geographic units one election event boundaries another event geographic standard. enables comparison election results across different boundary configurations providing ratios indicate source areas map target areas.

title: Prepare Boundary Correspondence for Cross-Election Comparison — prepare_boundaries
code: prepare_boundaries(   event = c("2025 Federal Election", "2023 Referendum", "2022 Federal Election",     "2019 Federal Election", "2016 Federal Election", "2013 Federal Election"),   compare_to = c("2025 Federal Election", "2023 Referendum", "2022 Federal Election",     "2021 Postcodes", "2021 Census", "2019 Federal Election", "2016 Federal Election",     "2016 Postcodes", "2016 Census", "2013 Federal Election", "2011 Postcodes",     "2011 Census"),   process = TRUE )

title: Prepare Boundary Correspondence for Cross-Election Comparison — prepare_boundaries
text: event Character string specifying source election event whose results want re-map. geographic base varies event: "2025 Federal Election" Uses 2021 ASGS SA1 boundaries "2023 Referendum", "2022 Federal Election", "2019 Federal Election" Use 2016 ASGS SA1 boundaries "2016 Federal Election" Uses 2011 ASGS SA1 boundaries "2013 Federal Election" Uses 2006 Census Collector Districts compare_to Character string specifying target boundaries map . Options include federal elections, referendums, Census SA1s, postcodes: Elections/Referendum Map CED boundaries event (e.g., "2025 Federal Election") Census Map SA1 boundaries Census year (e.g., "2021 Census") Postcodes Map Postal Areas year (e.g., "2021 Postcodes") process Logical. TRUE (default), removes geographic units correspondence ratios sum 1 (indicating data quality issues). FALSE, retains data issues warnings problematic units.

title: Prepare Boundary Correspondence for Cross-Election Comparison — prepare_boundaries
text: data frame containing boundary correspondence columns : Source geographic unit identifiers (CD SA1 codes) Target geographic unit identifiers (SA1, POA, CED) Ratio column(s) indicating proportion source mapping target exact columns depend event compare_to combination.

title: Prepare Boundary Correspondence for Cross-Election Comparison — prepare_boundaries
text: function central comparing election results across different boundary configurations. Australian electoral boundaries change due redistributions, ABS updates SA1 boundaries Census. function builds correspondence tables account changes. function works : Determining base geography source event Building correspondence chain target SA1 year via get_correspondence target POA CED, merging allocation tables via get_allocation_table recent elections (2022, 2023, 2025), applying redistribution adjustments via apply_redistribution_adjustments correct boundary changes occurred ABS allocation files published

title: Prepare Boundary Correspondence for Cross-Election Comparison — prepare_boundaries
text: event/compare_to combinations valid. Generally: can map forward time (older events newer boundaries) map boundaries earlier ASGS edition event uses

title: Prepare Boundary Correspondence for Cross-Election Comparison — prepare_boundaries
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   # Map 2019 election results to 2025 electoral boundaries   corresp <- prepare_boundaries(     event = "2019 Federal Election",     compare_to = "2025 Federal Election"   )    # Map 2022 election results to 2021 postcodes   corresp <- prepare_boundaries(     event = "2022 Federal Election",     compare_to = "2021 Postcodes"   )    # Map 2013 election results (CD-based) to 2021 SA1 boundaries   corresp <- prepare_boundaries(     event = "2013 Federal Election",     compare_to = "2021 Census"   ) } # }

what: Process Election Data by Census Collection District — process_ccd
title: Process Election Data by Census Collection District — process_ccd
text: Standardises column names election data across 2013, 2016, 2019, 2022 Australian federal elections ensure consistency. function adjusts year-specific column names common set, including renaming vote counts statistical area identifiers, removes redundant columns. unrecognised election year provided, data returned unprocessed message.

title: Process Election Data by Census Collection District — process_ccd
code: process_ccd(data, event)

title: Process Election Data by Census Collection District — process_ccd
text: data data frame containing election data event column indicating election year (e.g., "2013", "2016", "2019", "2022") year-specific columns state_ab, div_nm, pp_id, pp_nm, vote area identifiers (e.g., votes, count, ccd_id, SA1_id). event character string specifying election event process. Recognised values "2013 Federal Election", "2016 Federal Election", "2019 Federal Election", "2022 Federal Election". values result data returned unprocessed.

title: Process Election Data by Census Collection District — process_ccd
text: data frame. recognised election events ("2013 Federal Election", "2016 Federal Election", "2019 Federal Election", "2022 Federal Election", "2023 Referendum"), contains standardised columns: date (present input) event (election event) StateAb (state abbreviation) DivisionNm (division name) StatisticalAreaID (statistical area identifier; refers 2011 ASGC 2013–2016, 2016 ASGC 2019–2022) PollingPlaceID (polling place identifier) PollingPlaceNm (polling place name) Count (indicative count votes cast per statistical area) year column, present, removed redundant event. unrecognised election years, original data frame returned unchanged.

title: Process Election Data by Census Collection District — process_ccd
text: function processes election data : Applying base column renaming common recognised years using rename_cols() (e.g., state_ab StateAb, div_nm DivisionNm). Removing year column, event column already provides information. 2013: Renaming ccd_id StatisticalAreaID count Count. 2016 2019: Renaming SA1_id StatisticalAreaID votes Count. 2022: Renaming ccd_id StatisticalAreaID votes Count. unrecognised years: Returning data unprocessed informative message. function assumes input data frame contains required columns specified event year, though column names may vary per original datasets. Note StatisticalAreaID reflects different Australian Statistical Geography Standards (ASGC) depending year: 2011 ASGC 2013 2016, 2016 ASGC 2019 2022.

title: Process Election Data by Census Collection District — process_ccd
code: # Sample 2013 data data_2013 <- data.frame(   event = "2013 Federal Election",   state_ab = "NSW",   div_nm = "Sydney",   pp_id = 101,   pp_nm = "Sydney Town Hall",   ccd_id = "12345",   count = 500,   year = 2013 ) process_ccd(data_2013, "2013 Federal Election") #> Processing `2013 Federal Election` data to ensure all columns align across all elections. #>                   event StateAb DivisionNm PollingPlaceID #> 1 2013 Federal Election     NSW     Sydney            101 #>     PollingPlaceNm StatisticalAreaID Count #> 1 Sydney Town Hall             12345   500  # Sample 2019 data data_2019 <- data.frame(   event = "2019 Federal Election",   state_ab = "VIC",   div_nm = "Melbourne",   pp_id = 102,   pp_nm = "Melbourne Central",   SA1_id = "67890",   votes = 600 ) process_ccd(data_2019, "2019 Federal Election") #> Processing `2019 Federal Election` data to ensure all columns align across all elections. #>                   event StateAb DivisionNm PollingPlaceID #> 1 2019 Federal Election     VIC  Melbourne            102 #>      PollingPlaceNm StatisticalAreaID Count #> 1 Melbourne Central             67890   600  # Sample invalid year data_2021 <- data.frame(event = "2021 Federal Election", state_ab = "QLD", votes = 100) process_ccd(data_2021, "2021 Federal Election") #> No processing required for `2021 Federal Election`. Data returned unprocessed. #>                   event state_ab votes #> 1 2021 Federal Election      QLD   100

title: Process Polling Place Coordinates — process_coords
text: Updates missing invalid coordinate data polling places "Polling place" dataset Australian federal elections. helper function fills missing (NA) zero-valued latitude longitude coordinates matching PollingPlaceID internal coordinate dataset (coords) stored scgElectionsAU package namespace. function processes data specified election year, ensuring alignment known polling place locations.

title: Process Polling Place Coordinates — process_coords
code: process_coords(data, event)

title: Process Polling Place Coordinates — process_coords
text: data data frame containing polling place data single election event. Must include: event (election event, e.g., "2004 Federal Election", "2010 Federal Election") PollingPlaceID (unique identifier polling places) Latitude (latitude coordinate, potentially NA 0) Longitude (longitude coordinate, potentially NA 0) date column typically present mandatory metadata. event character string specifying election event (e.g., "2004 Federal Election", "2010 Federal Election"). Used logging purposes ; processing occurs years.

title: Process Polling Place Coordinates — process_coords
text: data frame identical input, updated columns: Latitude (updated non-NA, non-zero values internal coords dataset matches found) Longitude (updated non-NA, non-zero values internal coords dataset matches found) Unmatched already valid coordinates remain unchanged.

title: Process Polling Place Coordinates — process_coords
text: function processes polling place coordinates : Retrieving internal data: Accesses coords dataset scgElectionsAU package namespace, contains known PollingPlaceID, Latitude, Longitude values. Matching polling places: Uses PollingPlaceID match rows input data internal coords dataset. Updating coordinates: Replaces NA zero values Latitude Longitude corresponding values coords matches exist. Logging: Outputs message indicating election year processed, though processing applies universally regardless year. function assumes input data frame contains required columns (event, PollingPlaceID, Latitude, Longitude) sourced AEC "Polling place" dataset, internal coords dataset available correctly formatted within package namespace.

title: Process Polling Place Coordinates — process_coords
code: # Sample data with missing coordinates data_2010 <- data.frame(   date = "2010-08-21",   event = "2010 Federal Election",   PollingPlaceID = c(93925.0, 11877.0),   Latitude = c(NA, 0),   Longitude = c(0, NA) ) process_coords(data_2010, "2010 Federal Election") #> Filling in missing coordinates for `2010 Federal Election` data, where possible. #>         date                 event PollingPlaceID  Latitude Longitude #> 1 2010-08-21 2010 Federal Election          93925 -35.23895  149.0691 #> 2 2010-08-21 2010 Federal Election          11877 -35.43119  149.0830  # Sample data with some valid coordinates data_2013 <- data.frame(   date = "2013-09-07",   event = "2013 Federal Election",   PollingPlaceID = c(93925.0, 11877.0),   Latitude = c(-37.81, -33.87),   Longitude = c(144.96, 151.21) ) process_coords(data_2013, "2013 Federal Election") #> Filling in missing coordinates for `2013 Federal Election` data, where possible. #>         date                 event PollingPlaceID Latitude Longitude #> 1 2013-09-07 2013 Federal Election          93925   -37.81    144.96 #> 2 2013-09-07 2013 Federal Election          11877   -33.87    151.21

what: Process Election Data for Elected Candidates — process_elected

Applies datasets including "National list candidates" (House Senate), "First preferences candidate vote type" (House ), "Two candidate preferred candidate vote type" (House ), "Two candidate preferred candidate polling place" (House ), "Distribution preferences candidate division" (House ).

title: Process Election Data for Elected Candidates — process_elected

title: Process Election Data for Elected Candidates — process_elected
code: # Sample 2004 data data_2004 <- data.frame(   date = "2004-10-09",   event = "2004 Federal Election",   CandidateID = 123,   Elected = "#" ) process_elected(data_2004, "2004 Federal Election") #> Processing `2004 Federal Election` data to ensure all columns align across all elections. #>         date                 event CandidateID Elected #> 1 2004-10-09 2004 Federal Election         123       Y  # Sample unprocessed year (e.g., 2010) data_2010 <- data.frame(   date = "2010-08-21",   event = "2010 Federal Election",   CandidateID = 456,   Elected = "Y" ) process_elected(data_2010, "2010 Federal Election") #> No processing required for `2010 Federal Election`. Data returned unprocessed. #>         date                 event CandidateID Elected #> 1 2010-08-21 2010 Federal Election         456       Y

title: Process Overseas Voting Data — process_overseas
text: data frame. recognised election years ("2013", "2019", "2022", "2023", "2025"), contains standardised columns: date (present input) event (election event) StateAb (state abbreviation, standardised using amend_names() 2013 2019) DivisionNm (division name) OverseasPost (name overseas voting post) PrePollVotes (pre-poll vote count) PostalVotes (postal vote count) TotalVotes (sum PrePollVotes PostalVotes, NA handling) Rows missing StateAb values (e.g., totals) removed 2013 data. unrecognised election years, original data frame returned unchanged.

title: Process Overseas Voting Data — process_overseas
text: function processes overseas voting data : Standardising column names consistent set across recognised election years using rename_cols(). 2013 data: Removing unnecessary columns (pp_sort_nm, Total) rows NA StateAb. Converting full state names abbreviations using amend_names() 2013 2019 data. Calculating TotalVotes sum PostalVotes PrePollVotes, treating NA 0. unrecognised years: Returning data unprocessed informative message. function assumes input data frame contains required columns specified event year "2013", "2019", "2022", "2025", though column names may vary per original datasets.

title: Process Overseas Voting Data — process_overseas
code: # Sample 2013 data data_2013 <- data.frame(   event = "2013 Federal Election",   StateAb = c("NSW", "VIC", NA),   DivisionNm = c("Sydney", "Melbourne", "Total"),   pp_nm = c("London", "Paris", "All"),   `Pre-poll Votes` = c(100, 150, 250),   `Postal Votes` = c(50, 75, 125),   pp_sort_nm = c("LON", "PAR", "ALL"),   Total = c(150, 225, 375),   check.names = FALSE ) process_overseas(data_2013, "2013 Federal Election") #> Processing `2013 Federal Election` data to ensure all columns align across all elections. #>                   event StateAb DivisionNm OverseasPost PrePollVotes #> 1 2013 Federal Election     NSW     Sydney       London          100 #> 2 2013 Federal Election     VIC  Melbourne        Paris          150 #>   PostalVotes TotalVotes #> 1          50        150 #> 2          75        225  # Sample invalid year data_2026 <- data.frame(event = "2026 Federal Election", StateAb = "QLD", Votes = 100) process_overseas(data_2026, "2026 Federal Election") #> No processing required for `2026 Federal Election`. Data returned unprocessed. #>                   event StateAb Votes #> 1 2026 Federal Election     QLD   100

what: Process Pre-Poll Voting Centre Data — process_ppv
title: Process Pre-Poll Voting Centre Data — process_ppv
text: Standardises transforms Pre-Poll Voting Centre (PPVC) data single Australian federal election event consistent long-format structure. function aligns column names across election years (2010, 2013, 2016, 2019, 2022, 2025), pivots date-specific vote counts long format (except 2022-25), converts issue dates Date objects. unrecognised election years, data returned unprocessed message.

title: Process Pre-Poll Voting Centre Data — process_ppv
code: process_ppv(data, event)

title: Process Pre-Poll Voting Centre Data — process_ppv
text: data data frame containing PPVC data single election event. Must include event column single unique value (e.g., "2010", "2013", "2016", "2019", "2022", "2025"). Additional required columns vary year: State, Division, date-specific vote columns 2010; State, Division, m_pp_nm 2013; m_state_ab, m_div_nm, m_pp_nm 2016 2019; State, Division, PPVC, Issue Date, Total Votes 2022. date column optional. event character string specifying election event process. Recognised values "2010 Federal Election", "2013 Federal Election", "2016 Federal Election", "2019 Federal Election", "2022 Federal Election". values result data returned unprocessed.

title: Process Pre-Poll Voting Centre Data — process_ppv
text: data frame standardised columns recognised election years: date (present input) event (election event) StateAb (state abbreviation) DivisionNm (division name) PollingPlaceNm (polling place name; included 2013, 2016, 2019, 2022 ) IssueDate (date vote issuance Date object) TotalVotes (total votes issued corresponding issue date) 2010–2019, data pivoted wide long format using date-specific vote columns. 2022, data retains original structure renamed columns. unrecognised years, original data frame returned unchanged.

title: Process Pre-Poll Voting Centre Data — process_ppv
text: function processes PPVC data : Standardising column names across recognised election years using rename_cols(): 2010: Division DivisionNm. 2013: “DivisiontoDivisionNm`, `m_pp_nm` `PollingPlaceNm`. 2016 2019: `m_state_ab` `StateAb`, `m_div_nm` `DivisionNm`, `m_pp_nm` `PollingPlaceNm`. 2022-25: `Division` `DivisionNm`, `PPVC` `PollingPlaceNm`, `Issue Date` `IssueDate`, `Total Votes` `TotalVotes`. 2010: Filtering rows NA `DivisionNm` (e.g., notes totals). 2010–2019: Pivoting date-specific vote columns long format `pivot_event()`, creating `IssueDate` `TotalVotes` columns. 2022-25: Selecting standardised columns without pivoting. Converting `IssueDate` Date object using year-specific formats: 2025: "%d/%m/%Y" (e.g., "03/05/2025") 2022: "%d/%m/%y" (e.g., "09/05/22") 2019: "%d/%m/%Y" (e.g., "29/04/2019") 2016: "%Y-%m-%d" (e.g., "2016-06-14") 2013: "%d/%m/%Y" (e.g., "20/08/2013") 2010: "%d %b %y" (e.g., "02 Aug 10") unrecognised years: Returning data unprocessed informative message. function assumes input data frame contains required columns specified `event` year `event` column single unique value matching `event` argument.

title: Process Pre-Poll Voting Centre Data — process_ppv
code: # Sample 2013 data (wide format) data_2013 <- data.frame(   date = 2013-09-07,   event = "2013 Federal Election",   StateAb = "NSW",   DivisionNm = "Sydney",   m_pp_nm = "Sydney PPVC",   `20/08/2013` = 100,   `21/08/2013` = 150,   check.names = FALSE ) process_ppv(data_2013, "2013 Federal Election") #> Processing `2013 Federal Election` data to ensure all columns align across all elections. #>   date                 event StateAb DivisionNm PollingPlaceNm #> 1 1997 2013 Federal Election     NSW     Sydney    Sydney PPVC #> 2 1997 2013 Federal Election     NSW     Sydney    Sydney PPVC #>    IssueDate TotalPPVs #> 1 2013-08-20       100 #> 2 2013-08-21       150  # Sample 2022 data (long format) data_2022 <- data.frame(   date = 2022-05-21,   event = "2022 Federal Election",   StateAb = "VIC",   DivisionNm = "Melbourne",   PPVC = "Melbourne PPVC",   `Issue Date` = "09/05/22",   `Total Votes` = 200,   check.names = FALSE ) process_ppv(data_2022, "2022 Federal Election") #> Processing `2022 Federal Election` data to ensure all columns align across all elections. #>   date                 event StateAb DivisionNm PollingPlaceNm #> 1 1996 2022 Federal Election     VIC  Melbourne Melbourne PPVC #>    IssueDate TotalPPVs #> 1 2022-05-09       200  # Sample invalid year data_2024 <- data.frame(event = "2024 Federal Election", StateAb = "QLD", Votes = 100) process_ppv(data_2024, "2024 Federal Election") #> No processing required for `2024 Federal Election`. Data returned unprocessed. #>                   event StateAb Votes #> 1 2024 Federal Election     QLD   100

what: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Date — process_pva_date
title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Date — process_pva_date
text: Standardises transforms Postal Vote Application (PVA) data single Australian federal election event consistent long-format structure based application receipt dates. function aligns column names across election years (2010, 2013, 2016, 2019), pivots date-specific vote counts long format, converts receipt dates Date objects. unrecognised election years, data returned unprocessed message.

title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Date — process_pva_date
code: process_pva_date(data, event)

title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Date — process_pva_date
text: data data frame containing PVA data single election event. Must include: date (date election data snapshot) event (election event, matching event argument) Additional required columns vary year: 2010: Enrolment, date-specific columns (e.g., "02 Aug 10"). 2013: Enrolment Division, date-specific columns (e.g., "20-Aug-13"). 2016: State_Cd, PVA_Web_2_Date_Div, date-specific columns (e.g., "20160614"). 2019: State_Cd, PVA_Web_2_Date_V2_Div, date-specific columns (e.g., "20190411"). event character string specifying election event process. Recognised values "2010 Federal Election", "2013 Federal Election", "2016 Federal Election", "2019 Federal Election". values result data returned unprocessed.

title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Date — process_pva_date
text: data frame standardised columns recognised election years: date (date election data snapshot) event (election event) StateAb (state abbreviation, upper case; "ZZZ" NA 2013) DivisionNm (division name) DateReceived (date PVA received, Date object) TotalPVAs (total PVA applications received corresponding date) unrecognised years, original data frame returned unchanged.

title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Date — process_pva_date
text: function processes PVA data : Standardising column names across recognised election years using rename_cols(): 2010: Enrolment DivisionNm. 2013: Enrolment Division DivisionNm. 2016: State_Cd StateAb, PVA_Web_2_Date_Div DivisionNm. 2019: State_Cd StateAb, PVA_Web_2_Date_V2_Div DivisionNm. Handling missing states: 2013, NA StateAb replaced "ZZZ". Filtering rows: 2010 2013, rows NA DivisionNm (e.g., notes totals) removed. Removing unnecessary columns: Drops columns like "TOTAL date (Inc GPV)" (2010, 2013), "<>", "Date range" (2019). Pivoting data: Uses pivot_event() transform date-specific columns (e.g., "20-Aug-13") long format DateReceived TotalPVAs. Converting dates: Formats DateReceived Date object using year-specific formats: 2019: "%Y%m%d" (e.g., "20190411") 2016: "%Y%m%d" (e.g., "20160614") 2013: "%d-%b-%y" (e.g., "20-Aug-13") 2010: "%d %b %y" (e.g., "02 Aug 10") Formatting: Converts StateAb uppercase. Unrecognised years: Returns data unprocessed informative message. function assumes input data frame contains required columns (date, event, year-specific columns) AEC past results datasets event column matches event argument. date-specific columns represent daily PVA totals pivoted DateReceived TotalPVAs columns.

title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Date — process_pva_date
code: # Sample 2010 data data_2010 <- data.frame(   date = "2010-08-21",   event = "2010 Federal Election",   StateAb = "VIC",   Enrolment = "Melbourne",   `02 Aug 10` = 50,   `03 Aug 10` = 60 ) process_pva_date(data_2010, "2010 Federal Election") #> Processing `2010 Federal Election` data to ensure all columns align across all elections. #> [1] date         event        StateAb      DivisionNm   DateReceived #> [6] TotalPVAs    #> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)  # Sample invalid year data_2022 <- data.frame(   date = "2022-05-21",   event = "2022 Federal Election",   StateAb = "QLD",   Votes = 90 ) process_pva_date(data_2022, "2022 Federal Election") #> No processing required for `2022 Federal Election`. Data returned unprocessed. #>         date                 event StateAb Votes #> 1 2022-05-21 2022 Federal Election     QLD    90

what: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Party — process_pva_party
title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Party — process_pva_party
text: Standardises transforms Postal Vote Application (PVA) data single Australian federal election event consistent structure. function aligns column names across election years (2010, 2013, 2016, 2019), calculates totals Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) applications (online paper) combined AEC-plus-party applications, ensures uniform set columns. unrecognised election years, data returned unprocessed message.

title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Party — process_pva_party
code: process_pva_party(data, event)

title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Party — process_pva_party
text: data data frame containing PVA data single election event. Must include event column single unique value (e.g., "2010 Federal Election", "2013 Federal Election", "2016 Federal Election", "2019 Federal Election"). Additional required columns vary year: 2010: Enrolment, party-specific columns (e.g., Labor, Liberal, AEC). 2013: Enrolment Division, additional party columns (e.g., Liberal-National). 2016 2019: State_Cd, PVA_Web_1_Party_Div, AEC-specific columns (e.g., AEC - OPVA). date column optional. event character string specifying election event process. Recognised values "2010 Federal Election", "2013 Federal Election", "2016 Federal Election", "2019 Federal Election". values result data returned unprocessed.

title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Party — process_pva_party
text: data frame standardised columns recognised election years: date (date election data snapshot) event (election event) StateAb (state abbreviation, upper case; "ZZZ" NA 2013) DivisionNm (division name) GPV (general postal voter applications; included 2013, 2016, 2019 ) AEC (Online) (AEC online applications; included 2013, 2016, 2019 ) AEC (Paper) (AEC paper applications; included 2013, 2016, 2019 ) AEC (Total) (sum AEC online paper applications; years) Total (AEC + Parties) (sum AEC total party applications; years except 2010) ALP (Australian Labor Party applications; years) CLP (Country Liberal Party applications; years) DEM (Australian Democrats applications; 2019 ) GRN (Greens applications; 2010, 2013, 2016 ) LIB (Liberal Party applications; years) LNP (Liberal National Party applications; 2013, 2016, 2019 ) NAT (National Party applications; years) OTH (party applications; years) unrecognised years, original data frame returned unchanged.

title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Party — process_pva_party
text: function processes PVA data : Standardising column names across recognised election years using rename_cols(): 2010: Enrolment DivisionNm, party names (e.g., Labor ALP). 2013: Enrolment Division DivisionNm, additional party names (e.g., Liberal-National LNP). 2016 2019: State_Cd StateAb, PVA_Web_1_Party_Div DivisionNm, AEC columns (e.g., AEC - OPVA AEC (Online)). Handling missing states: 2013, NA StateAb replaced "ZZZ". Filtering rows: 2010 2013, rows NA DivisionNm (e.g., notes totals) removed. Calculating totals: 2013, 2016, 2019: AEC (Total) sum AEC (Online) AEC (Paper). Total (AEC + Parties) sum AEC (Total) party columns present. Column selection: Selects reorders columns consistent set, retaining present data. Formatting: Converts StateAb uppercase. Unrecognised years: Returns data unprocessed informative message. function assumes input data frame contains required columns specified event year event column matches event argument.

title: Process Postal Vote Application Data by Party — process_pva_party
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Sample 2010 data data_2010 <- data.frame(   date = "2010-08-21",   event = "2010 Federal Election",   StateAb = "VIC",   Enrolment = "Melbourne",   Labor = 120,   Liberal = 180,   AEC = 60 ) process_pva_party(data_2010, "2010 Federal Election")  # Sample 2013 data with NA in State data_2013 <- data.frame(   date = "2013-08-21",   event = "2013 Federal Election",   StateAb = NSW,   `Enrolment Division` = "Sydney",   `Liberal-National` = 150,   `AEC - OPVA` = 25,   `AEC - Paper` = 15,   check.names = FALSE ) process_pva_party(data_2013, "2013 Federal Election")  # Sample invalid year data_2022 <- data.frame(event = "2022 Federal Election", StateAb = "QLD", Votes = 90) process_pva_party(data_2022, "2022 Federal Election") } # }

title: scgElectionsAU (development version 0.0.1)
text: initial release scgElectionsAU, R package designed provide comprehensive data analytical tools Australia’s federal election results 2001 2022. development version marks first step offering robust resource political scientists, researchers, students, anyone interested intricacies Australia’s electoral processes.
